docs.lead_paragraph: The buzz in Washington is that education offers the new administration its one early chance for bipartisanship, but that George W. Bush's stubborn pursuit of his $1.3 trillion tax cut could kill such cooperation in the cradle. But the critics of Mr. Bush's plans may be wrong in their pessimism. In fact, his big tax cut could be the basis for achieving a different and surprising bipartisan endgame in 2001 that even President Clinton would have to applaud: extending health insurance to most of the 43 million Americans who lack it. Here's how. For starters, Mr. Bush knows that in the new divided Congress he won't be able to pass his tax cut as conceived in the campaign. Democrats and even moderate Republicans resist cuts in marginal rates and elimination of the estate tax in ways that shower most benefits on wealthy Americans, even if they pay the bulk of the taxes.

headline.main: What Tax Cuts Can Buy For Health

docs.abstract: Op-Ed article by Matthew Miller says critics of Pres-elect Bush's planned $1.3 trillion tax cut might feel differently if Bush agreed to put big chunk of tax cut into health coverage; says there would be bipartisan support for extending health insurance to most of 43 million Americans who lack it; explains how Bush could do this; drawing (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: It is easy to forget how beleaguered the Democratic Party was at the dawn of the 1990's. A generation had come of age with only the dimmest of memories of a successful Democratic presidential campaign.

headline.main: A Revival and a Party Transformed

docs.abstract: Article in series The Clinton Legacy focuses on Pres Clinton's role in restoring Democrats' national stature; cites his success in dealing with perceptions of Democratic Party that had become easy targets for Republicans; notes he sought to rein in government excesses so that government could again be progressive force; notes party followed his march to center, despite concerns over whether he ceded too much to right, reacted too much to polls and endangered party's soul; photos (M)
docs.snippet: It is easy to forget how beleaguered the Democratic Party was at the dawn of the 1990's.    A generation had come of age with only the dimmest of memories of a successful Democratic presidential campaign.

docs.lead_paragraph: The medical privacy rules issued last week by the Clinton administration did a good job in giving patients the right to protect their medical records from disclosure without their consent. The rules govern virtually every doctor, hospital, pharmacy and health insurance plan in the country, providing the first comprehensive federal standards for ensuring medical privacy. The new rules, which go into effect in two years, will require doctors and hospitals to get written consent from patients before disclosing medical information in written, electronic or oral communication. Patients can sign a single consent form in their first visit to a doctor or hospital that would authorize routine future disclosures for the purpose of their medical treatment or payment of insurance claims. But disclosures for other purposes -- for example, to employers making personnel decisions or to banks or insurance companies -- will require separate consents.
docs.abstract: Editorial hails Clinton administration's new medical privacy rules; holds they provide first comprehensive federal standards for protecting medical records from disclosure without patient's consent

docs.lead_paragraph: More than 50,000 elderly and disabled Connecticut residents are being forced to change health insurance carriers by Jan. 1 because many health maintenance organizations are getting out of the Medicare market. As a result, thousands must either change health plans or return to traditional Medicare, which does not cover costly prescriptions.

headline.main: Elderly Worry As Insurers Cut Medicare Plans For 50,000

docs.abstract: More than 50,000 elderly and disabled Connecticut residents will have to change to more costly health insurance carriers by January 1 because their HMO's are getting out of Medicare market (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: As his turbulent first term approached its close in 1996, Bill Clinton faced one of the most consequential decisions of his presidency: whether to sign a popular welfare bill largely shaped by his Republican enemies. Many of his allies saw the bill's get-tough features as an unthinkable surrender of victories won in the New Deal and the Great Society. In signing the measure, they said, Mr. Clinton would push millions of poor people and minorities deeper into poverty. Worse, many suspected he would be doing so for his own short-term political gain.

headline.main: A War on Poverty Subtly Linked to Race

docs.abstract: Third article in series, The Clinton Legacy, focuses on Pres Clinton's efforts to redefine welfare; Clinton's contentious drive to 'end welfare as we know it' stands as embodiment of his broader approach to problems of poverty and race; Clinton blended causes of left and right in ways that unsettled both, pursuing bold, some say risky, antipoverty strategy that he hoped would attract public support and avoid racial backlash that burdened previous programs for poor; at its heart was demand that poor go to work, even those with young children, low skills and low wages; supporters of program said that taxpayers would be far more generous to needy once they viewed poor as workers, not welfare cheats; Clinton imposed strict time limits and gave vast local discretion to turn needy away; as result, Clinton leaves far fewer protections for families who, for whatever reason, fail to hold jobs; at same time, he has presided over unprecedented expansion of aid for poor families who do work; photos (L)

byline.original: By JASON DePARLE and STEVEN A. HOLMES

docs.lead_paragraph: The Towa Pharmaceutical Company, Japan's biggest maker of generic drugs, said today that sales of off-patent drugs in Japan were poised to increase as the aging population continues to put pressure on the nation's health care budget. On a volume basis, generic drugs have 10 percent of the market in Japan, compared with 42 percent in the United States and 58 percent in Britain. Many Japanese have a poor image of the quality of generic drugs, and doctors here are not prone to write prescriptions for them.

headline.main: Japan May Turn To Generic Drugs

docs.abstract: Towa Pharmaceutical Co, Japan's biggest maker of generic drugs, says that sales of off-patent drugs in Japan are poised to increase as aging population continues to put pressure on the nation's health care budget; generic drugs have 10 percent of Japanese market compared with 42 percent in United States; many Japanese have poor image of generics and doctors do not prescribe them often; Towa is confident of change (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Re ''Aetna to Shed Customers and Jobs in Effort to Cut Health Care Costs'' (front page, Dec. 19): Health plans in the marketplace have failed to control health care costs, and they have failed to fill the gaping voids in coverage. Yet politicians continue on a path to increase the involvement of these failed models of ''reform'' by expanding their participation in our public programs of coverage, including Medicare, the Children's Health Insurance Program and Medicaid.

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: President Clinton's initiative to protect the privacy of patient records is a noble one (front page, Dec. 20). During the last few years, insurance carriers have routinely held up claims pending receipt of confidential records. Copies of records are often requested for dates that precede the date of coverage.

headline.main: Our Medical Records, in a Cocoon

docs.lead_paragraph: IN the six years he was in the House of Representatives and the 20 he has been in the Senate, Charles E. Grassley made it a practice to reserve the hours of 3 p.m. to 5 p.m. every day he was in Washington for meetings with outsiders. His constituents from Iowa always had first crack. Then came lobbyists, reporters and others interested in specific issues or legislation. He almost always had time for everyone, and often had time to spare.

headline.main: Critical Player on Bush Agenda Is an Unknown Quantity

docs.abstract: Public Lives column interview with Sen Charles E Grassley, conservative Republican who will head Finance Committee, moving from relative obscurity to post with dominant voice on most of top items on Pres-elect George W Bush's agenda; lobbyists and policy advocates are now anxious to meet with him, in part because his stands on agenda issues are unknown; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Rolner Saintlouis will spend this Christmas as he has spent the last 141 days: in a hospital room by his wife's side. His wife, Lucienne, 47, was paralyzed in an accident in August after Mr. Saintlouis lost control of the car he was driving. The car, carrying the couple and their three children, Franzdy, 19, Rosena, 15, and Rosenie, 11, flipped four times before coming to rest upside-down on an embankment on the side of Interstate 87 near Albany.
